children.name: to laugh in a cruel or nasty way
snigger / snicker
children.definition: sniggerbritish /snickeramerican /ˈsnɪgəʳ, ˈsnɪkəʳ/  to laugh quietly at something that is not supposed to be funny, for example when someone is hurt or embarrassed:
examples: cười khẩy
▪ ruth tripped and fell as she walked up the steps. the boys behind her sniggered.
▪ as he walked across the stage, billy could hear people snickering and whispering.

children.name: laugh at sb
children.definition: laugh at/ˈlɑːf ætǁˈlæf-/  to laugh or make unkind jokes about someone, because you think they arestupidorsilly:
examples: cười chê ai
▪ the other children laughed at lisa because her clothes were old-fashioned.
▪ at first i was terrified of being laughed at.

children.name: make fun of sb/ st
children.definition: make fun of/meɪk ˈfʌn ɒv/  to make someone or something seem stupid by laughing at them, or by saying things that make other people laugh at them:
examples: giễu cợt ai
▪ stop making fun of me!
▪ the other girls used to make fun of the way she spoke.

children.name: jeer
children.definition: /dʒɪəʳ/  if a group of people jeer at someone in a public place, they laugh unkindly at that person and shout rude things at them: nhạo báng, chế giễu ai
examples: ▪ the boys jeered as she ran away.
▪ he was booed and jeered by the spectators when he argued with the umpire.
jeer at nhạo báng, chế giễu
▪ after the match the crowd were all jeering at him.

children.name: to laugh because st is funny
giggle
children.definition: /ˈgɪgəl/  to laughquietlyandrepeatedlylike achildbecause of something funny or because you are nervous or embarrassed:
examples: cười khúc khích
▪ she giggled nervously and went bright pink.
giggle at/over cười khúc khích
▪ linda and christina were giggling at some private joke.
giggle[countable noun] nụ cười khúc khích
▪ there were a few smothered giggles from the girls sitting by the pool.
fit of giggles tràn cười khúc khích
▪ she collapsed in a fit of giggles.

children.name: laugh
children.definition: /lɑːfǁlæf/  to laugh because something is funny or because you are enjoying yourself: cười
examples: ▪ i laughed all the way through the film.
▪ i thought dad would be angry, but he just laughed.
laugh about cười về
▪ i couldn’t understand what they were all laughing about.
laugh at cười
▪ no-one laughed at his jokes.
burst out laughing: phì cười
suddenly laugh loudly
▪ we just looked at each other and burst out laughing.
laugh[countable noun] tiếng cười
give a laugh bật cười
▪ she gave a little nervous laugh and glanced towards robyn.

children.name: chuckle
children.definition: /ˈtʃʌkəl/  to laughquietly, especially because you are thinking about something funny:
examples: cười thầm
▪ ‘do you remember when michelle fell in the river?’ morgan chuckled.
chuckle at/about cười thầm về
▪ ‘we used to get up to all kinds of mischief.’ she chuckled at the memory.
chuckle to yourself tự cười thầm
▪ simon sat reading a magazine, chuckling to himself.
chuckle[countable noun] tiếng cười thầm
give a chuckle bật lên tiếng cười thầm
▪ he gave a low, knowing chuckle.

children.name: laughter
children.definition: /ˈlɑːftəʳǁˈlæf-/  the sound you make when you laugh:
examples: tiếng cười
▪ we could hear laughter coming from the next room.
roar with laughter bật cười lớn
laugh very loudly
▪ the show was a great success, and had the audience roaring with laughter.
burst/gurgle/snort etc of laughter tiếng cười lớn, róc rách, khịt mũi
▪ there was a burst of laughter when he appeared.
▪ thelma gave a gurgle of laughter.

children.name: have a laugh
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈlɑːfǁ-ˈlæf/  especially british if people have a laugh about something, they all laugh about it together: bật cười
examples: have a laugh about/at bật cười về
▪ when i realised my mistake, we had a laugh about it.
have a good laugh tiếng cười vui vẻ
▪ it was a bit scary at the time, but afterwards we all had a good laugh.

children.name: titter
children.definition: /ˈtɪtəʳ/  to laugh quietly in a high voice, because you are nervous, embarrassed, or slightly amused: cười gượng
examples: ▪ as the teacher read the poem someone tittered.
titter[countable noun] nụ cười gượng
▪ ‘that could be dangerous!’ said someone, and a titter ran round the room.

children.name: crack sb up
children.definition: crack somebody up/ˌkræk somebody ˈʌp/  informal to be very funny and to make people laugh a lot: làm ai đó cười nghiêng ngã
examples: ▪ mr bean really cracks me up. he’s so funny.

children.name: make sb laugh
children.definition: make somebody laugh/ˌmeɪk somebody ˈlɑːfǁ-ˈlæf/  làm cho ai đó cười
examples: ▪ rachel used to make us all laugh by imitating the teacher.
▪ thanks for your letter. it really made me laugh.

children.name: raise a laugh
children.definition: /ˌreɪz ə ˈlɑːfǁ-ˈlæf/  to succeed in making people laugh, especially when they do not really feel like laughing: tạo nên tiếng cười
examples: ▪ none of my carefully-prepared jokes managed to raise a laugh.

children.name: have somebody in hysterics
children.definition: /stitchesalsohave somebody in fitsbritish /ˌhæv somebody ɪn hɪˈsterɪks, ˈstɪtʃz, ˌhæv somebody ɪn ˈfɪts/  to make someone laugh uncontrollably: làm ai đó cười không kiểm soát được
examples: ▪ roger had us in hysterics with his account of his disastrous trip to italy.
▪ the cast included paul shane, whose quick wit had the audience in stitches.

children.name: amuse b2
children.definition: amuse/əˈmjuːz/  if something amuses someone, it makes them laugh or smile because it is fairly funny: cười vui vẻ
examples: ▪ something in the report had obviously amused him.
it amuses somebody to see/think something mọi người cười vui vẻ khi thấy, nghĩ về cái gì
▪ it amuses me to see politicians so eager to please at election time.
amuseverb[ i or t ]
to entertain someone, especially by humorous speech or action or by making someone laugh or smile
_i've brought with me an article from yesterday's paper that i thought might amuse you.
_[ + object + to infinitive ]i thinkitamuses himtosee people make fools of themselves.
_apparently these stories are meant to amuse.

children.name: roar with laughter
children.definition: roar/howl/shriek etc with laughter/ˌrɔːʳ wɪð ˈlɑːftəʳǁ-ˈlæf-/  to laugh very loudly because you think something is very funny: cười nghiêng ngả, cười lớn tiếng
examples: ▪ patsy chased him down the stairs, shrieking with laughter.
roar/howl/shriek etc with laughter at cười nghiêng ngả, cười lớn tiếng
▪ dad was roaring with laughter at something on tv and didn’t hear me come in.
▪ they howled with laughter at their own jokes.

children.name: laugh out loud
children.definition: /ˌlɑːf aʊt ˈlaʊdǁˌlæf-/  to suddenly laugh loudly because you think a situation, someone’s words, something you are reading etc is very funny: cười hằng hặc
examples: ▪ john threw back his head and laughed out loud.
▪ wodehouse is one of the few writers who can make me laugh out loud.

children.name: cackle
children.definition: /ˈkækəl/  to laugh loudly and unpleasantly in a high voice, like someone who is mad: cười chế nhạo
examples: ▪ when i said this, he started cackling like a madman.
▪ ‘oh we’ve got him now!’ i cackled, dancing round the room.
cackle[countable noun] nụ cười chế nhạo
▪ there was a cackle from the old lady. ‘i know what you’re after.’

children.name: roar/howl/peal etc of laughter
children.definition: /ˌrɔːr əv ˈlɑːftəʳǁ-ˈlæf-/  a very loud laugh: cười lớn tiếng
examples: ▪ with a roar of laughter, he lifted her off her feet and swung her round.
▪ everyone burst into peals of laughter.

children.name: to laugh a lot or for a long time
can’t stop laughing
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt stɒp ˈlɑːfɪŋǁˌkænt stɑːp ˈlæfɪŋ/  to be unable to stop yourself from laughing: không thể ngừng cười
examples: ▪ jonathan kept making funny faces at me and i just couldn’t stop laughing.
▪ it’s so embarrassing when everyone else is being serious and you can’t stop laughing.

children.name: laugh helplessly
children.definition: /uncontrollably/hysterically/ˌlɑːf ˈhelpləsli, ʌnkənˈtrəʊləbli, hɪˈsterɪkliǁˌlæf-/  to laugh so much that you cannot control yourself and could not stop laughing if you wanted to: cười không kiểm
examples: ▪ they both leant against the wall, laughing helplessly.
▪ she was laughing hysterically at the thought of mr taylor stepping out of his caravan with no clothes on.

children.name: have/get the giggles
children.definition: alsohave/get a fit of the giggles/ˌhæv, ˌget ðə ˈgɪgəlz, hæv, get ə ˌfɪt əv ðə ˈgɪgəlz/  british informal to be unable to stop yourself laughing, especially in a situation when you should not laugh: cười khúc khích
examples: ▪ it’s very difficult to be angry with somebody when you’ve got the giggles.
▪ i got a dreadful fit of the giggles - i couldn’t help myself!

children.name: laugh your head off
children.definition: /ˌlɑːf jɔːʳ ˈhed ɒfǁˌlæf-/  informal to laugh a lot and very loudly because of what someone says or does: cười nghiêng ngả
examples: ▪ when i told him what had happened, he laughed his head off.
▪ i can’t believe we were so stupid. our competitors must be laughing their heads off.

children.name: have hysterics
children.definition: /ˌhæv hɪˈsterɪks/  to laugh a lot continuously and uncontrollably because someone says or does something extremely funny or stupid: cười khùng khục
examples: ▪ everybody who heard this had hysterics.

children.name: fall about
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl əˈbaʊt/  british to laugh a lot in a very happy and cheerful way, especially because something has happened that you did not expect: bật ngửa
examples: ▪ when we heard the news, we just fell about!
fall about laughing bật ngửa vì cười
▪ when they saw what their father had done, they both fell about laughing.

children.name: i nearly/almost died
children.definition: /aɪ ˌnɪəʳli, ˌɔːlməʊst ˈdaɪd/ informal if you say i nearly or almost died, you mean that something made you laugh so much that you almost couldn’t stop laughing: sắp chết
examples: ▪ did you see the look on his face? i nearly died.
nearly/almost die laughing cười đến sắp chết
▪ he said this very solemnly, and they nearly died laughing.

children.name: gales/fits of laughter
children.definition: /ˌgeɪlz, ˌfɪts əv ˈlɑːftəʳǁ-ˈlæf-/  written a lot of laughter: một tràn cười
examples: ▪ jack put the phone down, and the children collapsed in gales of laughter.
▪ there was a brief stunned silence, and then the entire family went into fits of laughter.

children.name: keep a straight face
children.definition: /kiːp ə ˌstreɪt ˈfeɪs/  if you try to keep a straight face, you try not to laugh or smile, because it would be rude to laugh, or you do not want someone to know you are joking: giữ khuôn mặt lạnh lùng
examples: ▪ when reading some of the competition entries, it was hard to keep a straight face.
▪ ‘i think i’ve lost that camera you lent me,’ i said, trying to keep a straight face.
with a straight face bằng khuôn mặt lạnh lùng
▪ with a completely straight face, thomas announced he was joining the girl guides.
